title: 107_s904
content: The "Teacher Relief Act of 2001" allows above-the-line deduction for qualified professional development expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Teacher Relief Act of 2001" allows eligible educators to deduct up to $500 for qualified professional development expenses, including tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and transportation for qualified courses of instruction. A qualified course of instruction is directly related to the curriculum and academic subjects taught by an eligible educator, designed to enhance their ability to understand and use State standards, and provide instruction on teaching children. The curr_chunk discusses instruction for teaching children with different learning styles, disabilities, special needs, and how to discipline children in the classroom. It emphasizes the importance of aligning instruction with challenging State or local content standards. The curr_chunk focuses on the criteria for effective professional development for educators, emphasizing the need for programs that increase student academic achievement and teaching skills. It highlights the importance of intensive and lasting impact on educators' performance in the classroom. The curr_chunk discusses exemptions to certain activities in professional development plans for educators, emphasizing the need for approval and certification by the local educational agency. The curr_chunk defines an 'eligible educator' as a K-12 teacher, counselor, principal, or aide in an elementary or secondary school for at least 900 hours during a school year. It also clarifies the terms 'elementary school' and 'secondary school' as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The curr_chunk introduces a deduction for qualified professional development expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It specifies that no other deduction or credit shall be allowed for the same amount, and the deduction is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. The curr_chunk introduces amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow for a deduction under section 222. The curr_chunk introduces a new section, SEC. 30B, which provides a credit to elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The SEC. 30B section allows eligible educators a tax credit of 50% of qualified elementary and secondary education expenses, up to a maximum of $250 per year. Eligible educator and qualified expenses are defined in the section. The SEC. 30B section provides a tax credit to eligible educators for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses, such as classroom supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials. Special rules apply, including no double benefit and limitations on the credit amount based on the regular tax for the year. The SEC. 30B section provides a tax credit to eligible educators for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. A taxpayer may elect to have this section not apply for any taxable year. Tax credit for elementary and secondary school teachers providing classroom materials. Effective date: taxable years after December 31, 2001.
